{{other people|Heather Graham}} {{Use mdy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Heather Graham | image = Heather Graham, 2011 (cropped).jpg | imagesize = | caption = Graham at the [[2011 Toronto International Film Festival]] | birth_name = Heather Joan Graham | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|mf=yes|1970|1|29}} | birth_place = [[Milwaukee]], [[Wisconsin]], U.S. | nationality = American | occupation = Actress | years_active = 1984–present }}
'''Heather Joan Graham''' (born January 29, 1970) is an American actress. After appearing in television commercials, her first starring role in a feature film came with the teen comedy ''[[License to Drive]]'' (1988), followed by the critically acclaimed film ''[[Drugstore Cowboy]]'' (1989), which gained her initial industry notice.<ref>{{cite web|title=ABOUT HEATHER GRAHAM|url=https://movies.yahoo.com/person/heather-graham/biography.html|website=Yahoo!|accessdate=December 2, 2012}}</ref> She then played supporting roles in films such as ''[[Shout (film)|Shout]]'' (1991), ''[[Diggstown]] ''(1992), ''[[Six Degrees of Separation (film)|Six Degrees of Separation]]'' (1993), ''[[Swingers (1996 film)|Swingers]]'' (1996) and on the television series ''[[Twin Peaks]]'' (1991) and its prequel film ''[[Twin Peaks: Fire Walk with Me|Fire Walk with Me]]'' (1992), before gaining critical praise in [[Paul Thomas Anderson]]'s ''[[Boogie Nights]]'' (1997) as porn starlet Brandy, aka Rollergirl.<ref>{{cite news|last=Strauss|first=Bob|title=HEATHER'S COMMITMENT|url=http://infoweb.newsbank.com/iw-search/we/InfoWeb?p_action=doc&p_topdoc=1&p_docnum=1&p_sort=YMD_date:D&p_product=NewsBank&p_text_direct-0=document_id=(%200EAEE705995C065F%20)&p_docid=0EAEE705995C065F&p_theme=aggdocs&p_queryname=0EAEE705995C065F&f_openurl=yes&p_nbid=S50B5AENMTM1NDQ2NzM0NS4yNzMzODM6MToxMDoxMjguMTIuMC4w&&p_multi=LANB|work=Daily News of Los Angeles|accessdate=December 2, 2012}}</ref> In 1999, she co-starred in ''[[Bowfinger]]'' and ''[[Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me]]''.
In the 2000s, Graham starred in films ''[[Committed (2000 film)|Committed]]'' (2000), ''[[Say It Isn't So (film)|Say It Isn't So]]'' (2001), ''[[Mary (2005 film)|Mary]]'' (2005), ''[[Gray Matters (2006 film)|Gray Matters]]'' (2007), ''[[The Hangover (film)|The Hangover]]'' (2009) and its sequel, ''[[The Hangover Part III]]'' (2013). She also had a role on the television series ''[[Scrubs (TV series)|Scrubs]]'' in 2004, before playing the title character on the short-lived series ''[[Emily's Reasons Why Not]]'' in 2006. She also had recurring roles on Showtime's ''[[Californication (TV series)|Californication]]'' (2014) and Netflix's ''[[Flaked]]'' (2016).
Noted for portraying characters with sex appeal, she often appears in magazine lists of "Most Beautiful" and "Sexiest" women.<ref>{{cite web|title=Heather Graham — Peep Show|url=http://www.fhm.com/girls/covergirls/heather-graham|website=www.fhm.com|accessdate=December 2, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121115142611/http://www.fhm.com/girls/covergirls/heather-graham|archivedate=November 15, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Graham is a public advocate for [[Children International]],<ref name="Children International">{{cite web|url=http://www.children.org/celebrity |title=Children International |website=children.org |publisher=Children International |date= |accessdate=August 30, 2010}}</ref> and supported the [[climate change]] campaign [[Global Cool]] in 2007.
==Early life== Graham was born in [[Milwaukee]], [[Wisconsin]], at St. Michaels Hospital, the older of two children. Her family is of "three-quarters Irish" descent, with her father's side from [[County Cork]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/arts/2009/0610/grahamh.html |title=Heather Graham Interview — RTÉ Ten|website=RTÉ.ie|date=June 10, 2009 |accessdate=July 25, 2010}}</ref><ref>[http://www.irishcentral.com/ent/Heather-Graham-and-The-Hangover-boys-hit-up-Dublin-48488077.html "Heather Graham and 'The Hangover' boys hit up Dublin"] June 18, 2009, Irish Central</ref> Her younger sister, Aimee Graham, is also an actress, and writer. Their mother, Joan (née Bransfield), is a teacher and author of children's books.<ref>[http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qa3666/is_200610/ai_n17195051/ "Joan Bransfield Graham"] at CBS Business</ref> Their father, James Graham, is a retired [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] agent.<ref name="grouchoreviews.com">{{cite web|title=Heather Graham—Gray Matters—02/21/07|url=http://grouchoreviews.com/interviews/204|website=Groucho Reviews|accessdate=December 2, 2012}}</ref> The girls were raised [[Catholic Church|Catholic]].<ref name=HGFSIS>{{cite news|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:BGBK&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=0EADDD10454A8645&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=Heather Graham Finds Strangeness In 'Space'|accessdate=June 11, 2009|date=March 31, 1998|work=[[Boston Globe]]|author=Strauss, Bob}}</ref> Her family relocated repeatedly before moving to [[Agoura Hills, California|Agoura Hills]], California, when she was 9.<ref name=HC>{{cite news|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:LANB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=0EAEE705995C065F&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=Heather's Commitment|accessdate=June 11, 2009|date=April 28, 2000|work=[[Daily News of Los Angeles]]|author=Strauss, Bob}}</ref> She was introduced to acting during a school production of ''[[Adaptations of The Wizard of Oz|The Wizard of Oz]]''.
After high school, Graham enrolled in extension classes at the [[University of California, Los Angeles]], where she studied English for two years.<ref name=HGFSIS/> Despite her parents' objections, Graham withdrew from UCLA to pursue acting full-time.<ref>{{cite web|title=Biography :: Heather Graham|url=http://www.kalaajkal.com/biography/Heather-Graham|website=www.kalaajkal.com|accessdate=December 2, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140903201707/http://www.kalaajkal.com/biography/Heather-Graham|archivedate=September 3, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
==Career==
===Early work (1984–88)=== Graham's first film appearance was an uncredited cameo in ''[[Mrs. Soffel]]'' (1984).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.totalfilm.com/features/the-evolution-of-heather-graham/mrs-soffel-1984|title=The Evolution Of Heather Graham|first=Matt|last=Maytum|date=May 26, 2011|work=[[Total Film]]|accessdate=June 17, 2011}}</ref> Her first credited film appearance was in the television film ''[[Student Exchange]]''. In 1986, she appeared on a special "Teen Week" episode of the [[NBC]] game show ''[[Scrabble (game show)|Scrabble]]''. Then she appeared in numerous television commercials, and an episode of the sitcom ''[[Growing Pains]]'' in 1987. Her first high-profile starring role came in the [[Corey Haim]]/[[Corey Feldman]] vehicle ''[[License to Drive]]'' (1988), as a popular girl named Mercedes Lane, who serves as the love interest of Haim's character. Her efforts won her a [[Young Artist Award]] nomination in the ''Best Young Actress in a Motion Picture Comedy or Fantasy'' category. Her strict parents forbade her to accept a role in the [[black comedy]] ''[[Heathers]]'' (1988), which had an expletive-rich script.<ref name=HC/> The same year, she had an uncredited appearance as [[Danny DeVito]] and [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]]'s mother in ''[[Twins (1988 film)|Twins]]'' (during the laboratory conception flashback).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lebeauleblog.com/2012/09/05/what-the-hell-happened-to-heather-graham/|title=What The Hell Happened to Heather Graham}}</ref>
===From ''Drugstore Cowboy'' to ''Swingers'' (1989–1996)=== In 1989, Graham was featured in [[Gus Van Sant]]'s ''[[Drugstore Cowboy]]'' as Nadine, a young drug-addicted accomplice of the two main characters (played by [[Matt Dillon]] and [[Kelly Lynch]]). Her performance gave her career an initial boost and earned her a nomination for the [[Independent Spirit Award for Best Supporting Actress]]. She rejected a steady role in a soap opera and a three-picture deal with a major studio because she thought it would be too restrictive.<ref>{{cite web|last=Lou|first=Linda|title=The more risks, the more rewards|url=http://159.54.226.237/99_issues/990808/990808graham.html|work=USA Weekend Magazine |accessdate=December 2, 2012}}</ref> After ''Drugstore Cowboy'' she appeared in [[Lawrence Kasdan]]'s dark comedy ''[[I Love You to Death]]'' (1990), alongside [[William Hurt]] and [[Keanu Reeves]] and the rock-and-roll coming-of-age film ''[[Shout (film)|Shout]]'' (1991), for which she received a nomination for the [[Young Artist Award]] for Best Actress Starring in a Motion Picture.
After co-starring with [[Benicio del Toro]] in a [[Calvin Klein]] commercial directed by [[David Lynch]], the director cast her as Annie Blackburn in ''[[Twin Peaks]]'', where she appeared in the final six episodes. Following the show's cancellation, Graham reprised the role of Blackburn in the 1992 prequel film ''[[Twin Peaks: Fire Walk with Me]]''.<ref name="grouchoreviews.com"/>
She featured in ''[[Diggstown]]'' (1992), alongside [[James Woods]]; the well-received ''[[Six Degrees of Separation (film)|Six Degrees of Separation]]'' (1993), alongside [[Will Smith]]; and ''[[The Ballad of Little Jo]]'' (1993), alongside [[Ian McKellen]] before re-teaming with Gus Van Sant for the critically panned [[Even Cowgirls Get the Blues (film)|film adaptation]] of ''[[Even Cowgirls Get the Blues (novel)|Even Cowgirls Get the Blues]]'', alongside [[Uma Thurman]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Even Cowgirls Get the Blues (1994)|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/even_cowgirls_get_the_blues/|website=Rotten Tomatoes|accessdate=December 2, 2012}}</ref> The same year she co-starred as Mary Kennedy Taylor in ''[[Mrs. Parker and the Vicious Circle]]''. In 1995 she starred as Jackie in the poorly received ''Desert Winds'' and guest-starred in an episode of the television series ''[[Fallen Angels (TV series)|Fallen Angels]]''. She had a small but important role in ''[[Swingers (1996 film)|Swingers]]'' (1996), where she played Lorraine, [[Jon Favreau]]'s love interest.{{citation needed|date=May 2015}} She also played a small role as Maggie Bowen in ''[[Entertaining Angels: The Dorothy Day Story]]'' (1996).
===Wider industry and public recognition (1997–2003)=== Graham's popularity significantly increased after she appeared as Brandi, a young [[porn star]], nicknamed Rollergirl, in [[Paul Thomas Anderson]]'s critically acclaimed, award-winning ''[[Boogie Nights]]'' (1997). The cast received a nomination for the [[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Cast in a Motion Picture]]. The same year she also starred in the [[Gregg Araki]] film [[Nowhere (film)|Nowhere]], and had a cameo in the horror hit ''[[Scream 2]]''. She was subsequently cast in ''[[Two Girls and a Guy]]'' (1998),<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/two-girls-and-a-guy-1998|author=Ebert, Roger|title=TWO GIRLS AND A GUY|website=RogerEbert.com|publisher=Chicago Sun-Times|date=24 April 1998|}}</ref> a film mainly based upon dialogue between the characters which was shot in 11 days,<ref>{{cite news|last=McCarthy|first=Todd|title=Two Girls and A Guy|url=http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117329520/|work=Variety|accessdate=December 2, 2012}}</ref> which co-starred [[Robert Downey Jr.]] and [[Natasha Gregson]]; and the sci-fi film ''[[Lost in Space (film)|Lost in Space]]'', which was met with mostly negative reviews, and grossed $69,117,629 domestically on a production budget of $80 million. The cast was signed on for sequels that remain unmade.<ref>{{cite web|title=Lost in Space|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=lostinspace.htm|website=BoxOfficeMojo.com|accessdate=December 2, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Lost in Space (1998)|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/lost_in_space/|website=Rotten Tomatoes|accessdate=December 2, 2012}}</ref>
She starred as [[Felicity Shagwell]] in the sequel ''[[Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me]]'' (1999), which was a box-office hit. Shagwell is one of her best-known roles and became a fan favorite.<ref name="cineoutsider1">{{cite web|last=Raw|first=Timothy E.|title=The spy who misunderstood me|url=http://www.cineoutsider.com/articles/stories/h/heather_graham_interview.html|website=www.cineoutsider.com|accessdate=December 2, 2012}}</ref> Her turn as Shagwell also earned her a nomination for the [[Saturn Award for Best Actress]]. She appeared in the music video for [[Lenny Kravitz]]'s cover of "[[American Woman (song)|American Woman]]". Also in 1999, Graham co-starred as Daisy in the movie ''[[Bowfinger]]'', opposite [[Steve Martin]] and [[Eddie Murphy]].
The 2000 film ''[[Committed (2000 film)|Committed]]'' was her first starring vehicle. She played Joline, a devoted-beyond-reason young wife looking for the husband who left her. While the film itself received mixed-to-negative reviews, critics felt that "Graham shows she can play a central character" but noted "she's not enough to make ''Committed'' successful".<ref>{{cite web|title=Committed (2000)|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/1096844-committed/|website=Rotten Tomatoes|accessdate=December 2, 2012}}</ref> The following year she co-starred as Annie Matthews, an unhappily married woman, in [[Edward Burns]]' ''[[Sidewalks of New York (2001 film)|Sidewalks of New York]]''. In 2003, she starred with [[Joseph Fiennes]] in [[Chen Kaige]]'s English-language debut film ''[[Killing Me Softly (film)|Killing Me Softly]]'', which received overwhelmingly negative response from critics and a 0% at [[Rotten Tomatoes]], with the consensus being: "Respected director Chen Kaige's first English-language film is a spectacularly misguided erotic thriller, with ludicrous plot twists and cringe-worthy dialogue".<ref>{{cite web|title=Killing Me Softly (2002)|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/killing_me_softly/|website=Rotten Tomatoes|accessdate=December 2, 2012}}</ref> In 2009, the site also rated it No. 12 on the countdown of the worst films over the last ten years.
Graham's other appearances in mainstream fare include playing a fictionalized version of the [[Jack the Ripper]] murder victim [[Mary Jane Kelly|Mary Kelly]] in the film ''[[From Hell (film)|From Hell]]'' (2001), starring [[Johnny Depp]]; ''[[Anger Management (film)|Anger Management]]'' (2003), starring [[Adam Sandler]] and [[Jack Nicholson]]; the [[Farrelly Brothers]] comedy ''[[Say It Isn't So (film)|Say It Isn't So]]'' (2001), opposite [[Sally Field]]; ''[[The Guru (2002 film)|The Guru]]'', co-starring [[Jimi Mistry]] and ''[[Hope Springs (2003 film)|Hope Springs]]'' (2003), co-starring [[Colin Firth]].
===Focus on independent films and television (2004–08)=== [[File:Heather Graham cropped.jpg|thumb|alt=Graham smiling|upright|Graham in June 2007]] During this period, Graham starred in the independent films ''[[Gray Matters (2006 film)|Gray Matters]]'', ''[[Broken (2007 film)|Broken]]'', ''[[Adrift in Manhattan]]'' (all 2007) and ''[[Miss Conception]]'' (2008), which received negative-to-mixed reviews and most of them went largely unnoticed at the box-office.<ref>{{cite web|title=Gray Matters (2006)|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/gray_matters/|website=Rotten Tomatoes|accessdate=December 2, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Broken (2007)|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/1186122-broken/|website=Rotten Tomatoes|accessdate=December 2, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Adrift in Manhattan (2007)|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/adrift_in_manhattan/|website=Rotten Tomatoes|accessdate=December 2, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Miss Conception (2008)|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/1194135-miss_conception/|website=Rotten Tomatoes|accessdate=December 2, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Miss Conception|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=missconception.htm|website=BoxOfficeMojo.com|accessdate=December 2, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Gray Matters|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=graymatters.htm|website=BoxOfficeMojo.com|accessdate=December 2, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Adrift in Manhattan|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=adriftinmanhattan.htm|website=BoxOfficeMojo.com|accessdate=December 2, 2012}}</ref><ref name="cineoutsider1"/> Her 2005 film ''[[Mary (2005 film)|Mary]]'' holds a 63% fresh rating on [[Rotten Tomatoes]], her first "Fresh" film since ''Bowfinger''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mary (2005)|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/10005880-mary/|website=Rotten Tomatoes|accessdate=December 2, 2012}}</ref> The film premiered at the 2005 [[Venice Film Festival]] where it won the ''Special Jury Prize'' as well as three smaller awards. The film also played at the 2005 [[Toronto International Film Festival]], [[Deauville Film Festival]] and [[San Sebastián International Film Festival]] and co-starred [[Juliette Binoche]], [[Forest Whitaker]], [[Marion Cotillard]] and [[Matthew Modine]]. In 2006, she co-starred in ''[[Bobby (2006 film)|Bobby]]'' as Angela; the film's cast was nominated for a [[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Cast in a Motion Picture]].
During this period Graham also spoke about developing a comedy film titled ''The Accidental Virgin'' which would have focused on "female sexual confusion", telling the story of a woman who hasn't had sex in a year. The film has not been made. She also stated she would be interested in directing in the future if there is "something that, its burning in my mind that I need to do".<ref name="grouchoreviews.com"/>
On television, Graham played herself in an episode of the TV series ''[[Sex and the City]]''. She was given special guest-star status on nine episodes of [[NBC|NBC-TV's]] ''[[Scrubs (TV series)|Scrubs]]'' during its fourth season (2004–2005), and also appeared as [[George Michael Bluth]]'s ethics teacher in an episode of [[Fox Network|Fox's]] television series, ''[[Arrested Development (TV series)|Arrested Development]]'' in 2004. She played Emily Sanders in ''[[Emily's Reasons Why Not]]'', however, the sitcom was canceled after airing only one episode.
===''The Hangover'' and after (2009–present)=== In 2009, Graham played the [[hooker with a heart of gold|stripper with a heart of gold]], Jade, in ''[[The Hangover (film)|The Hangover]]'', which was released to critical and box office success. She won the role after [[Lindsay Lohan]] turned it down.<ref>{{cite web|title=Lindsay Lohan Turned Down Role in The Hangover|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/entertainment/news/lindsay-lohan-turned-down-role-in-the-hangover-200987|website=www.usmagazine.com|accessdate=December 2, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=The Hangover (2009)|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/10010667-hangover/|website=Rotten Tomatoes|accessdate=December 2, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=The Hangover|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=hangover.htm|website=BoxOfficeMojo.com|accessdate=December 2, 2012}}</ref> Though she did not return for the sequel ''[[The Hangover Part II]]'', she reprised her role in the final installment of the trilogy, ''[[The Hangover Part III]]''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Heather Graham Hints At Hangover III: ‘Something Good Happens To Jade’|url=http://www.accesshollywood.com/heather-graham-talks-fifty-shades-of-grey-and-hangover-iii-something-good-happens-to-jade_article_69727|website=www.accesshollywood.com|accessdate=December 2, 2012}}</ref> In 2010, she starred in ''[[Boogie Woogie (film)|Boogie Woogie]]'', followed by roles in the unsuccessful films ''[[Father of Invention]]'', ''[[5 Days of War]]'', ''[[Judy Moody and the Not Bummer Summer]]'' (all 2011) and ''[[About Cherry]]'' (2012).<ref>{{cite web|title=Father of Invention (2011)|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/father-of-invention/|website=Rotten Tomatoes|accessdate=December 2, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=5 Days Of War (2011)|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/5_days_of_war/|website=Rotten Tomatoes/|accessdate=December 2, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=About Cherry (2012)|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/about_cherry/|website=Rotten Tomatoes|accessdate=December 2, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Judy Moody and the NOT Bummer Summer (2011)|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/judy_moody_and_the_not_bummer_summer/|website=Rotten Tomatoes|accessdate=December 2, 2012}}</ref>
Graham voiced the character of Antonia Bayle in the online [[role-playing game]] ''[[EverQuest 2]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/news/6110496.html|title=SOE brings the erstwhile Saruman and Rollergirl on board its upcoming MMORPG.|accessdate=April 29, 2010|date=October 13, 2004|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|last=Thorsen |first= Tor|work=[[GameSpot]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://pc.gamespy.com/pc/everquest-ii/563930p1.html|title=Heather Graham talks EQ II|accessdate=April 29, 2010|date=November 5, 2004|author=Semel, Paul|publisher=IGN Entertainment|work=[[GameSpy]]}}</ref>
She played Meredith Crown in ''[[At Any Price (film)|At Any Price]]'', which stars [[Dennis Quaid]] and [[Zac Efron]] and was selected to compete for the Golden Lion at the 69th Venice International Film Festival, and later screened as an official selection at the Telluride and Toronto Film Festivals.<ref>{{cite web|title=Cinema|url=http://www.labiennale.org/en/cinema/festival/lineup/off-sel/venezia69/|website=www.labiennale.org|accessdate=December 2, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120728223053/http://www.labiennale.org/en/cinema/festival/lineup/off-sel/venezia69|archivedate=July 28, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Upcoming roles include mob lawyer Annette Stratton-Osborne in ''Behaving Badly'' and short story writer Mary Bellanova in ''My Dead Boyfriend'' (both 2014). She wrote a comedy screenplay called ''Half Magic'', which she stated she wants to direct. She said the story focuses on "these female friends and sexuality and about people having a sense of shame about sexuality and learning how to have a healthier attitude about it [...] It also deals with male/female relationships and sexism".{{citation needed|date=May 2015}}
In 2012, she was a member of the jury of the 15th [[2012 Shanghai International Film Festival|Shanghai International Film Festival]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-06-17/heather-graham-jean-jacques-annaud-judge-at-shanghai-film-fest.html|title=Heather Graham, Jean-Jacques Annaud Judge at Shanghai Film Fest|accessdate=March 5, 2013|date=June 17, 2012|website=bloomberg.com|publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.]]|author=Balfour, Frederik}}</ref>
In 2014, she starred in the second adaptation of the [[V. C. Andrews]] novel ''[[Flowers in the Attic]]'' on the Lifetime network. She played the character of Corrine Dollanganger; an evil mother who locks her four children in an attic in order to receive an inheritance from her dying father.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/07/lifetime-greenlights-flowers-in-the-attic-movie-with-heather-graham-ellen-burstyn/|title=Lifetime Greenlights ‘Flowers In The Attic’ Movie With Heather Graham & Ellen Burstyn |date=July 23, 2013 |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|author=Andreeva, Nellie |accessdate=November 8, 2014}}</ref> Graham also appeared in two TV-movie sequels based on the V.C. Andrews' series: ''[[Petals on the Wind]]'' and ''[[If There Be Thorns]]''; continuing to play the role of Corrine Dollanganger.<ref>{{cite web|title=Petals On The Wind Sequels If There Be Thorns And Seeds Of Yesterday Are Coming To Lifetime|url=http://www.cinemablend.com/television/Petals-Wind-Sequels-There-Thorns-Seeds-Yesterday-Coming-Lifetime-64313.html|website=CinemaBlend.com|accessdate=30 August 2015}}</ref> She appeared in the final season of ''[[Californication (TV series)|Californication]]'' as the mother of [[David Duchovny]]'s long-lost son.<ref>{{cite web|last=Roberts|first=Sheila|url=http://collider.com/heather-graham-at-any-price-hangover-3-interview/|title=Heather Graham Talks AT ANY PRICE, THE HANGOVER 3, Her Script HALF MAGIC, and CALIFORNICATION|work=Collider.com|accessdate=November 10, 2013}}</ref>
==Activism== Besides her acting work, Graham is also an activist who serves as a public advocate for [[Children International]].<ref name="Children International"/> She stated that what she likes about Children International is that "you are helping a child have a better life. It's great for that child to know that someone who lives in another country cares about them".<ref>{{cite web|title=Children International|url=http://pinterest.com/pin/111675265730021441/|website=pinterest.com|accessdate=December 3, 2012}}</ref> Graham works with the [[Cambodian Children's Fund]] which provides supplies and education, and campaigns to stop slavery. "There's a lot of human trafficking in Cambodia," Graham has said. "Women are dying because they don't have $15 to give birth in a hospital. The [Children's Fund] provides free education, clean water and healthcare for communities... We're creating future leaders who will be able to help themselves."<ref name="Children International"/><ref>{{cite news|last=LIipworth|first=Elaine|title=Heather Graham: I'm a nerd|url=http://www.news.com.au/news/heather-graham-im-a-nerd/story-fnejnq21-1226518061674|website=www.news.com.au|accessdate=December 3, 2012|date=November 17, 2012}}</ref> In 2007 she supported the [[climate change]] campaign [[Global Cool]] and appeared in [[Shekhar Kapur]]'s short film ''Global Cool'' alongside [[Sienna Miller]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Blair's acting debut in Shekhar film|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2007-06-11/europe/27971683_1_global-warming-shekhar-kapur-sienna-miller|accessdate=June 20, 2013|newspaper=times of india|date=June 11, 2007}}</ref>
==In the media== Graham is considered a [[sex symbol]]. She was ranked at number 40 in ''[[FHM]]'''s ''[[FHM's 100 Sexiest Women (UK)|100 Sexiest Women in the World]]'' list in 2000, number 95 in 2001 list, number 97 in the 2002 list, number #74 in the 2005 list and at number #98 in 2006 list. In 2001 she was named one of the ''50 Most Beautiful People'' by ''[[People (magazine)|People]]''. In 2003, she also posed for a photoshoot by photographer Sam Jones, during which she was levitated several feet into the air by a magician, who later also sawed her in half.<ref>{{cite web |author=FHM |url=http://www.fhm.com/girls/covergirls/heather-graham |title=FHM Covergirls – Heather Graham |website=FHM.com |date=December 10, 2008 |accessdate=July 25, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090831070050/http://www.fhm.com/girls/covergirls/heather-graham |archivedate=August 31, 2009 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Also in 2003, Graham appeared on the cover of ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine for an article titled "The Science of Meditation".<ref name="The Science of Meditation">[http://www.time.com/time/covers/0,16641,20030804,00.html "The Science of Meditation"] August 4, 2003, ''Time''</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Heather Graham — Peep Show|url=http://www.fhm.com/girls/covergirls/heather-graham|website=www.fhm.com|accessdate=December 3, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121115142611/http://www.fhm.com/girls/covergirls/heather-graham|archivedate=November 15, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref> To promote ''Emily's Reasons Why Not'', she had posed for a ''[[Life Magazine]]'' cover story, printed weeks in advance of the assumed series schedule, referring to her as "TV's sexiest star" which appeared in the January 27, 2006 issue.<ref>{{cite web| title=''Life Magazine'' Interview| url=http://www.editorandpublisher.com/eandp/news/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1001919450| website=editorandpublisher.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.defamer.com/hollywood/heather-graham/heather-grahams-permanent-weekend-151250.php |title=Defamer.com |website=Defamer.com |date=January 27, 2006 |accessdate=July 25, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081218134603/http://defamer.com/hollywood/heather-graham/heather-grahams-permanent-weekend-151250.php |archivedate=December 18, 2008 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
Graham is often cast in sexual roles including those of Felicity Shagwell (''Austin Powers: The Spy who Shagged Me''), porn stars Rollergirl (''Boogie Nights'') and Sharonna (''The Guru''), prostitute [[Mary Jane Kelly|Mary Kelly]] (''From Hell''), porn director Margaret (''About Cherry'') and stripper Jade (''The Hangover'' and ''The Hangover, Part III''). She stated she finds these types of roles and the issue of sexuality fascinating, and believes that "our culture sends out mixed messages to women about sex. Are women supposed to be sexually alive people, or are we supposed to be 'good' mothers who would never do those things?" and that she likes "the fact some of my roles maybe help people open their minds about the way they think about sex".<ref name="Heather Graham: I'm a nerd">{{cite news|title=Heather Graham: I'm a nerd|url=http://www.news.com.au/news/heather-graham-im-a-nerd/story-fnejnq21-1226518061674|website=www.news.com.au|accessdate=December 3, 2012|date=November 17, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Heather Graham - Biography|url=http://www.talktalk.co.uk/entertainment/film/biography/artist/heather-graham/biography/38|website=www.talktalk.co.uk|accessdate=December 3, 2012}}</ref><ref name="Heather Graham-Tantra">{{cite web|title=Heather Graham, 'tantra sex'|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/06/07/heather-graham-tantric-se_n_212240.html|website=huffingtonpost.com|accessdate=June 7, 2009}}</ref>
In 2005, Graham became the spokeswoman and TV model for the [[Garnier]] brand of hair care products.<ref>{{cite news|title=Heather Graham New Mane Attraction for Garnier 100% Color|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/heather-graham-new-mane-attraction-for-garnier-100-color-54281622.html|accessdate=August 30, 2015|website=prnewswire.com|date=April 13, 2005}}</ref>
==Personal life== Graham has been estranged from her parents in the past, supposedly due to their strict [[Irish Catholic]] beliefs and her rebellion as a teenager. Regarding the media's perception of her relationship with her parents, she stated: "I don't really like to talk about my parents. Because I just feel that it gets misinterpreted in the press..."<ref name="culture.com">{{cite web|title=Sidewalks of New York : Interview With Heather Graham|url=http://culture.com/articles/577/sidewalks-of-new-york-interview-with-heather-graham.phtml|website=culture.com|accessdate=December 2, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=The more risks, the more rewards|url=http://159.54.226.237/99_issues/990808/990808graham.html|website=USA Weekend Magazine|accessdate=December 2, 2012}}</ref>
She has been practicing [[Transcendental Meditation technique|transcendental meditation]] since 1991<ref name="Heather Graham-Tantra"/> after being introduced to it by [[David Lynch]]. She also expressed her dislike of [[reality television]], stating in a 2007 interview: "I think some of it, it seems strange – why do we all want to watch people be so miserable? Other people’s pain and misery – it seems kind of sad."<ref>{{cite web|title=Heather Graham Interviewed – 'Gray Matters' |url=http://collider.com/entertainment/interviews/archive_detail.asp/aid/3630/tcid/1/pg/2 |work=Collider.com |accessdate=November 10, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131110130524/http://collider.com/entertainment/interviews/archive_detail.asp/aid/3630/tcid/1/pg/2 |archivedate=November 10, 2013 }}</ref>

'''Hélène Boudreau''' (born June 19, 1969) is an [[Acadian]] and [[Métis people (Canada)|Métis]] Canadian artist and author of children's books, whose writing has appeared in various Canadian publications and her Maritime-themed art has been exhibited by the [[Toronto Public Library]] and other local vicinities.<ref name="Writers' Union">{{cite web|last=Boudreau|first=Helene|title=Members' Pages|url=http://www.writersunion.ca/ww_profile.asp?mem=1952&L=|work=Writers& Writing|publisher=The Writers' Union of Canada|accessdate=17 November 2011}}</ref>
==Early life== Hélène Boudreau was born and raised in [[Petit-de-Grat, Nova Scotia|Petit de Grat, Cape Breton, Nova Scotia]] in a French [[Acadian French|Acadian]] community to parents of Acadian and Métis descent and can speak both English and French fluently.<ref name="Authors' Booking Service">{{cite web|title=Hélène Boudreau|url=http://authorsbooking.com/2043/authors/Helene_Boudreau.html|work=Authors' Booking Service|publisher=Marsha Skrypuch, Valerie Sherrard|accessdate=17 November 2011}}</ref> She grew up in a large family having had three brothers and four sisters. After graduating from Isle Madame District High School in 1987, Boudreau attended [[Dalhousie University]] where she earned a degree in biology and began working as a Park Interpreter for the [[Canadian Parks and Wilderness Society|Canadian Parks Service]]. Afterwards she began training as a Registered Respiratory Therapist at the Victoria General School of Allied Health. It wasn't until she was in her late twenties when she moved to [[Ontario]] from her [[Maritimes|Maritime]] hometown in order to begin her career as a children's author.
==Career==
When asked what inspired Boudreau to become a children’s author, she recalled:
{{cquote|I first thought of a being a children's author in 4th/5th grade when a teacher of mine published a picture book. It was very inspirational for me to see someone I knew accomplish such an unimaginable feat. That day, I went straight home and wrote and illustrated a [[picture book]] of my own but it wasn't until much later (almost thirty years) when I actually put that dream of being an author into action.}}
In 2007, Boudreau was short-listed in the [[Surrey International Writers' Conference|Surrey International Writing Contest]], in the "Writing For Young People" category for ''With Measured Breath: A YA short story''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hélène Boudreau|url=http://www.writersunion.ca/ww_profile.asp?mem=1952&L=|work=The Writers' Union Of Canada|publisher=The Writers' Union Of Canada|accessdate=6 November 2011}}</ref> Shortly afterwards, Boudreau began working on her first book called ''Acadian Star'' after many years of having settled in Ontario. The novel was aimed at middle school children and tells the adventures of a young girl named Meg Gallant who takes part in a home town competition with her friend Neve, called the Acadian Star. It was published in 2008, by [[Nimbus Publishing]] and was soon nominated for the 2009/2010 ''Hackmatack Children’s Choice Award''. ''Acadian Star'' also took 2nd place in the 2008 ''Writers Federation of New Brunswick Literary Competition'', at which time Boudreau began accumulating a local fan base among younger readers in Eastern Canada.
The year 2010 saw the publishing of two more novels of Boudreau's titled ''KEEP OUT!'', by ''Nimbus Publishing'' and ''Real Mermaids Don't Wear Toe Rings'', by ''Jabberwocky Publishing'' about "an aquaphobic mer-girl trying to balance the drama of two-legged teenage life with her quest to rescue her mermaid mother from really scary mer-dudes".<ref name="website">{{cite web|last=Boudreau|first=Helene|title=From Publisher's Marketplace:|url=http://www.heleneboudreau.com/|work=Welcome to my Website !|publisher=Helene Boudreau|accessdate=15 November 2011}}</ref> The second was to become her best known book, a Crystal Kite Member Choice Finalist, and served as a prequel to ''Real Mermaids Don't Hold Their Breath'' (May, 2012) and ''Real Mermaids Don't Have Two Left Feet'' (February 2013).<ref>{{cite web|last=Boudreau|first=Helene|title=REAL MERMAIDS Cover Reveals !|url=http://www.heleneboudreau.com/?page_id=181|work=Hélène Boudreau|publisher=Helene Boudreau|accessdate=15 November 2011}}</ref> Ironically, Boudreau wrote most of her first novel in the ''Real Mermaids series'', Real Mermaids Don't Wear Toe Rings, on her feet. An avid walker, she stated "I find when you're on the move, it helps your thoughts be on the move, too."<ref>{{cite news|last=Gordon|first=Andrea|title=Bottoms Up: The Case for Walking while You Work|url=http://0-search.proquest.com.innopac.douglas.bc.ca/news/docview/853059636/132EC138DF5679BE828/7?accountid=10545|accessdate=6 November 2011|newspaper=The Toronto Star|date=22 February 2011}}</ref>
==Personal life== Boudreau married Gordon Clarke, a now retired lieutenant of 1989 and who is currently the 1st Vice President of the [[Royal Military College of Canada|Royal Military Colleges Club of Canada.]] They have two young daughters together, Charlotte and Marcelle.<ref name="Gordon Clarke">{{cite web|title=Ex-Cadets in the News|url=http://everitas.rmcclub.ca/?p=2525.|work=eVeritas|accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref> Although the family resides in [[Markham, Ontario]] presently, Boudraeu’s "birthplace [of Petit de Grat] greatly influences the themes of [her] writing for children." Boudreau is known to be "...a compulsive walker, a chicklet wrangler and a lover of cheese and cheap chocolate."<ref name="website" /> Authors that inspire Boudreau include [[Madeleine L’Engle]], [[Louis Sachar]], [[Katherine Paterson]] and [[Kate DiCamillo]]. She is also an active member of [[The Writers' Union of Canada]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Helene|first=Boudreau|title=Hélène Boudreau|url=http://authorsbooking.com/2043/authors/Helene_Boudreau.html|work=Author's Booking Service|publisher=Marsha Skrypuch, Valerie Sherrard|accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref>

{{Infobox person |name=Ignacy Hryniewiecki |image= I Grinevizky.jpg |image_size = 125px |caption= |birth_date={{Birth-date|1856}} |birth_place=Kalinovka, Klichev District, Russian Empire |death_date = {{Death-date|13 March 1881}} (aged 24-25) |death_place=St. Petersburg, Russia }} '''Ignacy Hryniewiecki''' ({{lang-pl|Ignacy Hryniewiecki}}; {{lang-ru|Игнатий Иоахимович Гриневицкий}}, ''Ignaty Ioakhimovich Grinevitsky''; party [[pseudonym]]: ''Kotik'', [[Russian language|Russian]] for "Kitten";<ref name="road">{{cite book|last=Yarmolinsky|first=Avrahm|title=Road to Revolution: A Century of Russian Radicalism|url=http://www.ditext.com/yarmolinsky/yar14.html}}</ref> 1856 – 13 March 1881) was a revolutionary and independence fighter, member of [[People's Will]] and the principal assassin of [[Tsar]] [[Alexander II of Russia]].
==Early life== Hryniewiecki was born in 1856 in Kalinovka, a village in [[Klichev]] District in present-day [[Belarus]]. His family was a noble family (or ''[[szlachta]]'') of a former [[Grand Duchy of Lithuania]]. According to his friend [[Lev Tikhomirov]], Hryniewiecki called himself a [[Litvin]].<ref>{{cite news|author=Васіль Герасімчык|title=Грынявіцкі, або проста «Коцік»|url=http://novychas.by/poviaz_casou/hryniavicki_abo_prosta_kocik/|publisher=Газэта «Новы час»|date=2016-03-01|access-date=2017-07-29}}</ref>
==Revolutionary life== In 1875 Hryniewiecki left for [[Saint Petersburg]], where he enrolled in mathematics at the Polytechnic. Soon he joined the Russian revolutionary ''[[Narodnaya Volya (organization)|Narodnaya Volya]]'' (People's Will) movement.
In 1880 Hryniewiecki, [[Andrei Zhelyabov]], [[Sophia Perovskaya]] and others were in charge of revolutionary [[propaganda]] among students and workers. Hryniewiecki was an organizer of the ''Workers' Gazette'' and a [[typesetter]] at a clandestine printing establishment.
==Assassination of Tsar== In February 1881 Hryniewiecki joined the bomb-throwing unit created to assassinate Tsar Alexander II.<ref name="road"/>
The night before the [[assassination]], Hryniewiecki wrote a letter to posterity, part of which reads:
{{quote|Alexander II must die. He will die, and with him, we, his enemies, his executioners, shall die too [...] How many more sacrifices will our unhappy country ask of its sons before it is liberated? It is my lot to die young, I shall not see our victory, I shall not live one day, one hour in the bright season of our triumph, but I believe that with my death I shall do all that it is my duty to do, and no one in the world can demand more of me [...]<ref>Abraham Yarmolinsky, Road to Revolution: A Century of Russian Radicalism, Princeton 1986, Page 276</ref>}}
On 13 March 1881, (1 March [[Old Style and New Style dates|O.S.]]<ref name="spartacus">{{cite web|title=Alexander II|url=http://www.spartacus-educational.com/RUSalexander2.htm|publisher=Spartacus Educational|accessdate=25 August 2013}}</ref>) Alexander II was traveling in a [[Carriage#Coach|two-seater carriage]].<ref name="road"/> An armed [[Cossack]] sat next to the coach-driver with Alexander II in the carriage while six other Cossacks followed on horseback.<ref name="spartacus"/> As the carriage approached a street corner near the Catherine Canal, Sophia Perovskaya gave the signal to [[Nikolai Rysakov]] and [[Timofei Mikhailov]] to throw their bombs.<ref name="spartacus"/> The Tsar was unharmed but two were wounded.<ref name="road"/> Alexander II insisted upon leaving the carriage to check on the wounded.<ref name="spartacus"/><ref name="kropotkin">{{cite book|last=Kropotkin|first=Peter|authorlink=Peter Kropotkin|title=Memoirs of a Revolutionist|publisher=[[Dover Publications]]|page=432|year=2010 (reproduction of 1899 edition)|ISBN=978-0-486-47316-1}}</ref> At this point Hryniewiecki, who was leaning against the railing by the canal fence, raised both arms and threw his bomb<ref name="spartacus"/><ref name="kropotkin"/> and the blast tore the Tsar apart.<ref name="road"/> Just before throwing the bomb he was alleged to have shouted "It is too soon to thank God", in response to the emperor saying "thank God I'm untouched" to the anxious inquires of his entourage.<ref>Robert K. Massie, Nicholas and Alexandra, Dell Publishing Company, New York, p.16</ref> Nearby, Hryniewiecki himself lay unconscious from the blast.<ref name="road"/>
Hryniewiecki was taken to the infirmary attached to the [[Winter Palace]]. At 9 PM he regained consciousness, refusing to give any information to the police. He died from his wounds at 10:30 PM.<ref>Abraham Yarmolinsky, Road to Revolution: A Century of Russian Radicalism, Princeton 1986, Page 280</ref>
The assassination had been meant to ignite revolution. Hryniewiecki's fellow-conspirators — [[Nikolai Kibalchich]], [[Sophia Perovskaya]], Nikolai Rysakov, Timofei Mikhailov, [[Andrei Zhelyabov]] — were sentenced to death and were hanged on 3 April 1881. They were buried in an anonymous common grave.
The [[Church of the Savior on Spilled Blood]] was erected on the site of the assassination.

{{small|John Harvey Kagezi}} }} '''Joan Namazzi Kagezi''' (14 July 1967 to 30 March 2015), was a [[Uganda]]n lawyer and prosecutor. At the time of her death, she was the [[State Attorney|assistant director of public prosecution]] and head of the International Criminal Division in Uganda's [[Ministry of Justice and Constitutional Affairs (Uganda)|Ministry of Justice and Constitutional Affairs]].{{cite web | title=Motorcycle Gunmen Kill Ugandan Prosecutor | date=31 March 2015 | url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/03/31/world/uganda-prosecutor-death/ | accessdate=4 April 2015 | publisher=[[Cable News Network]] | last=Ntale | first=Samson}} ==Background and education== She was born Joan Namazzi to Kaggwa Sserwadda and Mrs. Sserwadda of Luteete Village, [[Rakai District]], on 14 July 1967. She attended Nsuube Primary School from 1973 to 1980. She studied at [[Mount Saint Mary's College Namagunga]], an all-girls boarding senior secondary school in [[Mukono District]], for both her O-Level and A-Level education. In 1987, she entered [[Makerere University]] to study law, graduating in 1990 with a [[Bachelor of Laws]] degree. In 1992, she earned a Diploma in [[Legal practice|Legal Practice]] from the [[Law Development Centre]]. At the time of her death, she was pursuing a [[Master of Business Administration]] from the [[Eastern and Southern African Management Institute]].{{cite web | first=Lydia | newspaper=[[Daily Monitor]] | location=Kampala | last=Ainomugisha | url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/Magazines/Life/10-Life-lessons-from-Kagezi/-/689856/2675702/-/item/0/-/qwmpmt/-/index.html | title=10 Life Lessons From Kagezi | date=5 April 2015 | accessdate=5 April 2015}} ==Career== Throughout her 23-year career as an attorney, Kagezi served as a public servant with the [[government of Uganda]]. Straight out of the Law Development Centre in 1992, she secured a position as land officer in the [[Ministry of Lands, Housing and Urban Development (Uganda)|Ministry of Lands, Housing and Urban Development]]. In May 1994, she was appointed a [[state attorney]] in the Ministry of Justice and Constitutional Affairs. She received a promotion in February 2002 to principal state attorney. In August 2007, she was promoted to senior principal state attorney. In January 2015, she was appointed head of the International Crimes Division, at the rank of assistant director of public prosecutions. ==Death== On 30 March 2015, at about 7.30 pm local time, Kagezi, who was driving an official Ford double-cabin pick up with government number plates without security, stopped at a road-side stand to buy fresh vegetables in the [[Kampala]] suburb of [[Kiwaatule]]. Her intended final destination was her home in the adjacent neighbourhood called [[Najjera]]. In the pick-up with her were three of her four children, two girls and one boy. One of the girls left the vehicle to pick up the products while the rest of the family stayed in the vehicle. While the girl was walking back to the car, a man approached the truck. He knocked on the driver's window which was closed, appearing to be making an inquiry. When Kagezi opened the window, the man shot her twice in the neck at close range, jumped on the back of a waiting motor cycle (boda boda), and sped off.{{cite web | date=1 April 2015 | url=http://mobile.monitor.co.ug/News/News/Kagezi--the-name-synonymous-with-handling-high-profile-cases/-/2466686/2672352/-/format/xhtml/-/9p8acs/-/index.html | title=Kagezi, The Name Synonymous With Handling High Profile Cases | accessdate=5 April 2015 | first=Anthony | last=Wesaka | newspaper=[[Daily Monitor|Daily Monitor Mobile]]}} She was rushed to [[Mulago National Referral Hospital]], where she was pronounced [[dead on arrival]] at about 8.00 pm. She was 47 years old.{{cite web | accessdate=5 April 2015 | newspaper=[[Daily Monitor]] (Kampala) | last=Job Bwire, Stephen Otage | date=30 March 2015 | url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/News/National/Senior-Principal-State-Attorney-Joan-Kagezi-shot-/-/688334/2670954/-/5oaxy3/-/index.html | first=and Anthony Wesaka | title=Senior Principal State Attorney Joan Kagezi Shot Dead}}{{cite web | title=Lead Prosecutor in al-Shabaab Bombing Trial Shot Dead in Uganda | accessdate=5 April 2015 | url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/mar/30/uganda-prosecutor-al-shabaab-bombing-case-shot-dead-uganda | last=World News | date=30 March 2015 | newspaper=[[The Guardian]] Quoting [[Agence France-Presse]] in Kampala}}{{cite web | accessdate=5 April 2015 | url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-32125134 | first=Catherine | last=Byaruhanga | publisher=[[BBC News]] | title=Uganda Prosecutor in al-Shabab Bomb Case Shot Dead | date=31 March 2015}} ==Case load== Among the high-profile prosecutions that Joan Kagezi participated in or led, over her 21 years as a government prosecutor were the following: * The prosecution of Ugandan-born Australian cardiologist Aggrey Kiyingi for the assassination of his wife, lawyer Robinah Kasirye Kiyingi. She was gunned down in July 2005 outside the gate of the family mansion in [[Munyonyo|Buziga]], an upscale neighbourhood in Uganda's capital Kampala. The state lost that case.{{cite web| accessdate=6 April 2015| first=Anthony| location=Kampala|last=Wesaka |newspaper=[[Daily Monitor]]|url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/SpecialReports/-/688342/1376718/-/item/1/-/4oi81hz/-/index.html|title=Did The State Lose Interest in Pursuing Robinah Kiyingi Murder Appeal?|date=31 March 2012}} * The trial and conviction of former [[Arua|Arua Municipality]], Akbar Hussein Godi, whose wife was killed on 4 December 2008 in [[Mukono District]]. In February 2011, Godi was sentenced to 25 years in prison after being convicted of murdering Rehema Caesar Godi, who was 19 years old at the time of her death.{{cite web | title=MP Godi Jailed For 25 Years Over Murder | url=http://www.newvision.co.ug/new_vision/news/1016432/mp-godi-jailed-murder | accessdate=11 November 2016 | date=11 February 2011 | newspaper=[[New Vision]] | location=Kampala | last=Edward Anyoli | first=and Pascal Kwesiga}} * The prosecution and conviction of Kampala businessman Thomas Nkulungira, also known as "Tonku", whose girlfriend was killed sometime between 21 and 30 December 2010. Her body was dumped in the septic tank at Nkulungira's house in [[Muyenga]], a Kampala neighborhood. On 13 August 2011, a judge sentenced Tonku to death for capital murder.{{cite web | newspaper=[[New Vision]] | url=http://www.newvision.co.ug/new_vision/news/1006803/tonku-sentenced-death | accessdate=11 November 2016 | title=Tonku Sentenced To Death | date=13 August 2011 | location=Kampala | last=Andate Okanya | first=and Edward Anyoli}} * The prosecution of Thomas Kwoyelo, a warlord in the [[Lord's Resistance Army]], on charges of kidnapping, murder, rape, and human mutilation and torture.{{cite web | accessdate=6 April 2015 | url=http://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/thomas-kwoyelos-troubling-trial | date=20 July 2012 | title=Thomas Kwoyelo's Troubling Trial | first=Alexis | last=Okeowo | newspaper=[[The New Yorker]]}} The trial was terminated when Uganda's Constitutional Court granted Kwoyelo amnesty.{{cite web | location=London | url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-15019883 | title=Ugandan LRA Rebel Thomas Kwoyelo Granted Amnesty | date=22 September 2011 | accessdate=6 April 2015 | first=Joshua | last=Mmali | publisher=[[British Broadcasting Corporation]]}} On appeal, however, the [[Supreme Court of Uganda]] reversed that decision on 8 April 2015, sending the case back to the Uganda High Court for trial.{{cite web | date=9 April 2015 | url=http://www.newvision.co.ug/new_vision/news/1323851/kwoyelo-amnesty-plea-flops | title=Kwoyelo Amnesty Plea Flops | newspaper=[[New Vision]] | accessdate=11 November 2016 | first=Andante | last=Okanya | location=Kampala}} * The prosecution that was ongoing when Kagezi died of 13 individuals accused of participating in the [[July 2010 Kampala attacks]], which occurred during the [[2010 FIFA World Cup Final]] match, killing at least 79 people.{{cite web | title=Suicide Bomb Vest Found at Third Ugandan World Cup Venue As Police Hunt Suspects | first=Mike | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/uganda/7887598/Suicide-bomb-vest-found-at-third-Ugandan-World-Cup-venue-as-police-hunt-suspects.html | date=13 July 2010 | last=Pflanz | location=London | newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]] | accessdate=11 November 2016}} ==Family== While an undergraduate at [[Makerere University]] in the late 1980s, she met her future husband, Henry Morton Kagezi. He died of natural causes in 2006.{{cite web | accessdate=5 April 2015 | url=http://www.newvision.co.ug/news/666603-who-kills-a-widow-in-the-presence-of-her-children.html | title=Who Kills A Widow in the Presence of Her Children? | newspaper=[[New Vision]] | location=Kampala | date=2 April 2015 | first=Mike | last=Chibita}} Together, they hadtwo boys and two girls: George Phillip Kagezi born in 1993, Carol Milcah Kagezi born in 1994, Pearl Priscilla Kagezi born in 1999, and John Harvey Kagezi born in 2004. President [[Yoweri Museveni]] has pledged to pay the children's school fees until each child determines that he or she decides to end his or her education.{{cite web | accessdate=11 November 2016 | url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/News/National/pay-fees-Kagezi-children-Museveni/-/688334/2674252/-/5m5uqkz/-/index.html | date=2 April 2015 | title=I Will Pay Fees for Kagezi's Children – Says Museveni | last=Kakumirizi | first=Michael | newspaper=[[Daily Monitor]] | location=Kampala}}{{cite web | last=The Monitor Staff | url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/News/National/Museveni-visits-Kagezi-s-family/-/688334/2675288/-/1phldy/-/index.html | accessdate=5 April 2015 | title=Museveni Visits Kagezi's Family | date=3 April 2015 | newspaper=[[Daily Monitor]] | location=Kampala}} ==Search for her killers== On 8 April 2015, a heavily armed force of Ugandan and U.S. security officials apprehended [[Jamal Abdullah Kiyemba]], an individual formerly held in [[Guantanamo]]. While there was no conclusive evidence tying Kiyemba to the killing of Kagezi, detectives were questioning him about his possible role in that crime and a range of other offenses.{{cite web | accessdate=11 November 2016 | url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/jamal-kiyemba-former-guantanamo-prisoner-held-in-uganda-killing-1.3024388 | title=Jamal Kiyemba, former Guantanamo prisoner, held in Uganda killing: Local prosecutor killed last month in suburb of Kampala | publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]] Quoting [[The Associated Press]] | date=8 April 2015 | author=The Associated Press}}{{cite web | author=Vision Reporter | url=http://www.newvision.co.ug/new_vision/news/1323801/guantanamo-painful-experience-kiyemba | title=Guantanamo was a painful experience - Kiyemba | accessdate=11 November 2016 | date=8 April 2015 | newspaper=[[New Vision]] | location=Kampala}}{{cite web | title=Details emerge about Kagezi murder suspect | accessdate=11 November 2016 | date=8 April 2015 | newspaper=[[New Vision]] | last=Wandera | url=http://www.newvision.co.ug/new_vision/news/1323798/details-emerge-about-kagezi-murder-suspect | first=Alfred | location=Kampala}}{{cite web | last=Bariyo | url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/ugandan-police-arrest-former-guantanamo-bay-detainee-1428502011 | title=Ugandan Police Arrest Former Guantanamo Bay Detainee | accessdate=11 November 2016 | date=8 April 2016 | newspaper=[[Wall Street Journal]] | location=New York City | first=Nicholas}} ==See also== * [[Kale Kayihura]] * [[Kahinda Otafiire]] * [[Aronda Nyakairima]] * [[Jim Muhwezi]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kagezi, Joan}} [[Category:1967 births]] [[Category:2015 deaths]] [[Category:People from Rakai District]] [[Category:Ugandan lawyers]] [[Category:Ugandan women lawyers]] [[Category:Ganda people]] [[Category:Makerere University alumni]] [[Category:Law Development Centre alumni]] [[Category:Eastern and Southern African Management Institute alumni]] [[Category:People educated at Mount Saint Mary's College Namagunga]] [[Category:Ugandan Christians]]

'''Joe Krush''' (born May 18, 1918) and '''Beth Krush''' (March 31, 1918 – February 2, 2009) were an [[American people|American]] husband-and-wife team of illustrators who worked primarily on [[children's books]]. They may be known best for the U.S. editions of all five [[Borrowers]] books by [[Mary Norton (author)|Mary Norton]], published by Harcourt 1953–1961 and 1982, a series inaugurated very early in their careers.
==Life==
Beth <!--name?--> was born March 31, 1918 in [[Washington, DC]]. As a girl she enjoyed visiting the city institutions and special events and drawing at home.<ref name=degrummond/> Joseph Krush was born May 18, 1918 in [[Camden, New Jersey]], and raised there. As a boy he won some prizes for drawings of boats and planes.<ref name=degrummond/>
Beth and Joe both studied at the [[Philadelphia Museum School of Art]], where they met on the first day of class.<ref name=degrummond/> They married during World War II<ref name=degrummond/> and settled in [[Wayne, Pennsylvania]], south of the city, in 1948.<ref name=staino/> They still lived there when Beth died in 2009 (in [[Bryn Mawr, Pennsylvania]]).<ref name=staino/>
Joe has had a life-long love of aviation. He designed, built and flew award winning model aircraft since 1930. Joe has set numerous indoor freeflight records as a member of the Academy of Model Aeronautics and FAI. He helped organize the Valley Forge Signal Seekers (Pennsylvania) one of oldest Radio Control Model Airplane clubs in the USA. Joe is still active in mentoring students involved with the flying events in Science Olympiad as well as his long-standing art classes on illustrating.
The Krushes had one son, the musician [[Jay Krush|Jay Paul Krush]].<ref name=philly/> Joe Krush [[centenarian|turned 100]] in May 2018.<ref>http://6abc.com/community-events/wayne-artist-joe-krush-is-celebrating-his-100th-birthday/3492461/</ref>
==Career==
Joe worked as a graphic designer for O.S.S. during the war.<ref name=degrummond/> He was a [[courtroom sketch]] artist at the [[Nuremberg Trials]] 1945–1946. Beth taught illustration and drawing at [[Moore College of Art]] in Philadelphia, for at least 15 years.<ref name=UMN-beth/><!-- one source says 22 yrs; death notice says professor emeritus -->
Both of the Krushes illustrated books that [[Harcourt, Brace]] published in 1947.<!--earliest i have found, not known to be their debuts--> Joe did ''[[Windwagon Smith]] and Other Yarns'', a collection of short stories by [[Wilbur Schramm]].<ref name=isfdb-joe/> Beth did ''Mr. Doodle'' by Sally Scott.<ref name=LCC-doodle/> Sarah Scott Fisher, the daughter of [[Dorothy Canfield Fisher]],{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} was a prolific writer of children's picture books whom Harcourt teamed with multiple illustrators. The Library of Congress online catalog lists 16 Sally Scott and Beth Krush collaborations published from 1947 to 1963.
The Krushes planned to work separately but they helped each other meet deadlines and that collaboration was noticed and approved by editors.<ref name=degrummond/>
Beside ''[[The Borrowers]]'' and its sequels, some famous books illustrated jointly by the Krushes were ''[[Miracles on Maple Hill]]'' (1956) by [[Virginia Sorensen]] (who won the [[Newbery Medal]] as its writer); ''[[Gone-Away Lake]]'' and its sequel, by [[Elizabeth Enright]] (1957, 1961); and ''All-of-a-Kind Family Downtown'' by [[Sydney Taylor]] (1972).
Before collaborating with his wife, Joe Krush illustrated the dustjacket and the interior of ''Huon of the Horn'', published by Harcourt in 1951, an adaptation of ''[[Huon de Bordeaux]]'' that was [[Andre Norton]]'s first fantasy novel. A few years later he did the same for ''[[The Ponder Heart]]'' by [[Eudora Welty]], published in 1953/1954.
Beside collaborating with her husband, Beth Krush illustrated ''[[The Shoe Bird]]'' (1964), the only children's book by Eudora Welty.
There are two collections of Krush papers at the University of Minnesota and one item at the University of Southern Mississippi. All of the materials date from 1964 and earlier.<ref name=degrummond/><ref name=UMN-beth/><ref name=UMN/>

Lectron | signature = <!-- very optional --> | notable works = | awards = | website = | subcat = American | birth_date={{Birth date|1914|11|26}} | death_date={{Death date and age|1971|07|24|1914|11|26}} }} '''Louis Kenneth Fine''' (November 26, 1914 – July 24, 1971)<ref name=ssdi>[https://familysearch.org/ark:/61903/1:1:JTTN-HPY Louis Fine], at the United States [[Social Security Death Index]] via [[FamilySearch.org]]. Retrieved on January 8, 2016. Also [http://www.genealogybank.com/gbnk/ssdi/doc/ssdi/v1:112CE7EEC35B3CFB Louis Fine] at the United States Social Security Death Index via GenealogyBank.com. Death date given only as "July 1971".</ref><ref>Death date July 24 per [http://www.lambiek.net/artists/f/fine.htm Lou Fine] at the [[Lambiek Comiclopedia]]. {{webarchive |url=https://www.webcitation.org/62XODczri?url=http://www.lambiek.net/artists/f/fine.htm |date=2011-10-18 }} on October 18, 2011.</ref> was an [[United States|American]] [[comic book]] [[artist]] known for his work during the 1940s [[Golden Age of comic books]], where his draftsmanship became an influential model to a generation of fellow comics artists.
==Biography==
===Early life and career=== [[Image:HitComics5.jpg|thumb|left|''Hit Comics'' #5 (Nov. 1940). This cover, used in ''The [[Jim Steranko|Steranko]] History of Comics 2'' (1972), helped introduce Fine's art to a new generation.]] Lou Fine was born in either the [[Manhattan]]<ref name=dennis3>{{cite journal|last=Beaulieu|first=Dennis| title=A Comic Book Artist of Quality| magazine=[[Alter Ego (magazine)|Alter Ego]]| volume= 3| number=17 |date = September 2002}}</ref> or [[Brooklyn]]<ref name=elliot15>Interview with son Elliot Fine, ''Alter Ego'', p. 15: "He was probably born in Brooklyn". "His father was...probably a Russian immigrant, though I don't know where he was born".</ref> boroughs of [[New York City]], the son of a house painter, Meyer, who was possibly a [[Russia]]n immigrant.<ref name=elliot15 /> Fine's mother died while Fine was attending [[Cooper Union]] college, studying [[engineering]].<ref name=elliot15 /> He had an older brother, Sam, who died in October 2000, at age 86, and a sister.<ref name=elliot15 /> According to Fine's son Elliot, Lou Fine's family lived in the Brooklyn neighborhood of "[[East New York]], which was called [[Brownsville, Brooklyn|Brownsville]] in those days.... It was a [[tenement]] [[Jewish]] neighborhood back then".<ref name=elliot15 />
Either at about age two<ref name=elliot15 /> or in his early teens,<ref name=dennis3 /> Fine's left leg became crippled by polio.<ref name=dennis3 /> Developing a talent for art, and influenced by such commercial illustrators and other artists as [[Dean Cornwell]], [[Heinrich Kley]], and [[J. C. Leyendecker|J.C. Leyendecker]],<ref name=dennis3 /> Fine went on to study at Manhattan's [[Grand Central Art School]] and [[Brooklyn]]'s [[Pratt Institute]].<ref name=dennis3 /> In 1938, Fine, like many other comics artists of the time, found work at [[Eisner & Iger]], a prominent "packager" that supplied complete comic books to [[publishers]] testing the waters of the emerging [[mass media|medium]]. Fine's first published comics art was the strip "Wilton of the West" in [[Fiction House]]'s ''[[Jumbo Comics]]'' #4 (Dec. 1938), signed with the house [[pen name]] '''Fred Sande'''<ref name=berk>{{cite web|last=Berk |first=John |url=http://www.comicartville.com/loufine.htm |title=Lou Fine |publisher=Comicartville Library |date=2004 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5scSgYFAB?url=http://www.comicartville.com/loufine.htm |archivedate=September 9, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> (which strip originator [[Jack Kirby]] had used in previous issues). Other early [[pseudonyms]] Fine employed (reflecting the fledgling Eisner & Iger's attempts to convince publishers they had a large stable of artists) were '''Curt Davis''' and '''Basil Berold'''. Eisner would later say, "I had respect for his towering kind of draftsmanship. He was the epitome of the honest draftsman. No fakery, no razzle-dazzle — very direct, very honest in his approach".<ref name=berk />
Fine went on to do exquisite and acclaimed work for [[Fox Feature Syndicate]], where he supplied the cover of 1939's ''[[Blue Beetle]]'' #1 and drew such features as "[[Flame (comics)|The Flame]]" in ''Wonderworld Comics'' and the later eponymous series. For publisher [[Everett M. "Busy" Arnold]]'s [[Quality Comics]], he drew features including "[[Black Condor|The Black Condor]]" (initially under the pseudonym '''Kenneth Lewis''') in ''Crack Comics''; "[[Doll Man]]" (under the pseudonym '''William Erwin Maxwell''') in ''Feature Comics''; "[[Ray (comics)|The Ray]]" (initially under the jokey pseudonym '''E. Lectron''') in ''Smash Comics''; "[[Uncle Sam (comics)|Uncle Sam]]" (for which Eisner & Iger co-founder [[Will Eisner]] received credit) in ''National Comics''; and "Stormy Foster" in ''Hit Comics''. Fine became particularly prominent as a cover artist.
Fine, along with ''[[Plastic Man]]'' creator [[Jack Cole (artist)|Jack Cole]], was a ghost-artist on Will Eisner's celebrated Sunday-supplement [[newspaper]] comic book ''[[The Spirit]]'' during Eisner's [[World War II]] [[Conscription|military service]], Fine inking over Cole's pencil work. Some of these were reprinted in Quality's ''Police Comics'' and ''The Spirit'' comic book, where Fine's work continued to appear through 1949, five years after Fine had left comics.
[[Joe Simon]], an artist and the first editor of [[Marvel Comics]], called Fine his "favorite artist.... He was also Jack Kirby's favorite artist. I know that Jack was a fan of and greatly influenced by Fine’s work".<ref name=berk />
===Advertising and comic strips=== Leaving comic books in 1944, Fine segued into [[newspapers]] by drawing Sunday [[advertising]] comics. Starting out at [[Johnstone and Cushing]],<ref>Heintjes, Tom. "Funny Business: The Rise and Fall of Johnstone and Cushing". Hogan's Alley (online magazine), via cartoonician.com.</ref> he formed his own company with Don Komisarov,<ref>https://www.lambiek.net/artists/f/fine.htm</ref> whom he had met doing ''The Throp Family'' for ''[[Liberty Magazine]]'' in 1946. He had many accounts, but his two most enduring were the series he did for Philip Morris and the Sam Spade strip for Wildroot haircream.<ref>samples of both on the Fabulous Fifties (http://www.allthingger.blogspot.com)</ref>
He later drew the [[comic strips]] ''Taylor Woe'' (1949), ''Adam Ames'' (1959) and ''Peter Scratch'' (1965). In a single return to comic books, he contributed to a [[toy]] company's custom one-shot, ''[[Wham-O]] Giant Comics'' (1967), illustrating a two-page story, "The Man From Aeons", starring a [[prehistoric]] man who, though named "Tor", was not the [[Tor (comic book)|same-name caveman character]] created in the 1950s by [[Joe Kubert]].
Fine also worked on the strip ''Space Conquerors'' in the magazine ''[[Boys' Life]]'' from the late 1960s until his death. He and writer [[Gill Fox]], whom he had met during his time with Eisner & Iger and remained in contact with, were developing new comic strips when Fine was found dead of a [[myocardial infarction|heart attack]] at the threshold of his studio.<ref name="gillfox">Interview with Gill Fox, ''Will Eisner's Shop Talk'' (Dark Horse, Milwaukie, Oregon, 2001) {{ISBN|1-56971-536-X}}</ref>
===Later life=== By the late 1960s, Fine lived in affluent [[Lido Beach, New York]], on [[Long Island]], owning two houses there. Friend and collaborator Gill Fox described them as, "One for his wife and one for himself. He lived alone [by then]".<ref name="gillfox" />
==Critical assessment== '''Atlas Comics''' (retailer), "The Top 100 Artists of American Comic Books": #10 - Lou Fine: "By God, Lou Fine could draw. One of comics' first illustrative stars, he influenced and astounded such later greats as [[Alex Toth]], [[Jim Steranko]], and [[Gil Kane]]. His covers alone during the ' 40s stand as some of the best-designed and most exciting work ever produced for any comic book publisher".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.acomics.com/best10.htm |title=Atlas Comics presents The Top 100 Artists of American Comic Books |publisher=Atlas Comics (retailer) |location=Chicago |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5syERAIE4?url=http://www.acomics.com/best10.htm |archivedate=September 24, 2010 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
==Collections== Fine's ''Spirit'' work has been reprinted in [[DC Comics]]' hardcover collections ''The Spirit Archives'' vols. 5 to 9 (2001–2003), spanning July 1942 to December 1944.
Selections of Fine's other comics works, including the Flame, Doll Man, Uncle Sam, the Ray, and Black Condor, have been reprinted in [[Pure Imagination (comics)|Pure Imagination]]'s ''Lou Fine Reader'', by [[Greg Theakston]], vols. 1 (2003, {{ISBN|1-56685-025-8}}) and 2.

{{More citations needed|date=April 2008}} {{Infobox person | name = Maria Dermoût | image = MariaDermout.jpg | image_size = | caption = Maria Dermoût in 1907 | birth_name = Helena Anthonia Maria Elisabeth Ingerman | birth_date = {{Birth date|1888|6|15|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Pati Regency|Pati]], Indonesia | death_date = {{Death date and age|1962|6|27|1888|6|15|df=yes}} | death_place = [[The Hague]], Netherlands | occupation = Novelist | years_active = }} '''Maria Dermoût''' (15 June 1888 – 27 June 1962), was an [[Indo people|Indo-European]] novelist, considered one of the greats of [[Dutch literature]] and as such an important proponent of [[Dutch Indies literature]]. In December 1958 [[Time (magazine)|''Time'' magazine]] praised the translation of Maria Dermoût's ''[[The Ten Thousand Things]]'', and named it one of the best books of the year. Whitney Balliett of ''The New Yorker'' wrote:
''"Mrs. Dermout, in the manner of Thoreau and the early Hemingway, is an extraordinary sensualist. [...] in passages of a startling, unadorned, three-dimensional clarity; often one can almost touch what she describes."''[http://www.nybooks.com/books/imprints/classics/the-ten-thousand-things/ New York Review Books website.] Retrieved 26 October 2011
==Biography== Dermoût was a Dutch novelist born in [[Pati Regency|Pati]], [[Central Java|Java]], [[Dutch East Indies]], and educated in the Netherlands, who wrote in [[Dutch language|Dutch]]. After completing her education she returned to [[Java (island)|Java]], where she married and travelled extensively across Java and the [[Maluku Islands|Moluccas]] with her husband. In 1933 her husband was pensioned, and the couple returned to the Netherlands. Maria Dermoût was widowed in 1952. Dermoût died in [[The Hague]] in 1962. She is the subject of the [[biography]] ''Geheim Indië. Het leven van Maria Dermoût 1888-1962'' ("The Secret East Indies. The Life of Maria Dermoût 1888-1962") in 2000 by the [[Indo people|Indo-European]] (Dutch-Indonesian) author [[Kester Freriks]]. ==Body of work== Dermoût turned to writing early in life, but remained largely unpublished until she was 63. She wrote two novels, both of which were not published until she was in her sixties: ''[[The Ten Thousand Things]]'' (''De tienduizend dingen'', 1955) and ''Days Before Yesterday'' — also published as ''Just Yesterday'' (''Nog pas gisteren'', 1951).Encyclopædia Britannica "Her first two novels, Nog pas gisteren (1951; Yesterday) and De tienduizend dingen (1955; The Ten Thousand Things), are fictionalized accounts of her youth. Although written in an economic style, the two novels are rich in details of island life as experienced by both the colonials and the native people" There are English translations of her novels by [[Hans Koning]]. Some of her [[Short story|short stories]] were published in translation in magazines such as ''[[Vogue magazine|Vogue]]'' during the 1960s. In Dutch, five short-story collections by her were also published. She is viewed as one of the giants among [[Dutch Indies literature|Dutch-Indies literary]] writers, and ''The Ten Thousand Things'' in particular is widely regarded as an idiosyncratic masterpiece. The book has been translated into thirteen languages. As Hans Koning puts it in his Introduction to the [[New York Review Books]] edition of the novel:
"Dermoût was sui generis, a case all her own. She did not write about her Indies as a Dutch woman, or as a Javanese or an [[Ambon Island|Ambonese]]. Hers was a near-compassionate disdain for the dividing lines, the hatreds and the fears ... She ''painted'' landscapes, [[still life]]s and people in a world of myth and mystery."
Although not conventionally [[Autobiography|autobiographical]], both of her novels draw from Dermoût's own life. In particular, like the central character in ''The Ten Thousand Things'', Dermoût lost her son in violent circumstances (he died in a Japanese [[prisoner-of-war camp]]). The Javanese childhood experiences and reminiscences described in ''Days Before Yesterday'' are based on, but do not mirror, her own childhood in the [[tropics]]. [[File:Dermout5.JPG|thumb|Grave headstone]] Author [[Oek de Jong]] appropriately wrote:
''"Still, Maria Dermoût an author for the happy few. Is she a writer's writer? Certainly not. She is a storyteller par excellence. Her stories are subtle, but they are also accessible. Nonetheless she remains an author for the happy few, equal to the greats of Dutch prose, but much less known than they are. There are many reasons for her modest literary reputation: her own modesty, the small body of her work, the brevity of her literary career. But it is mainly her work itself that is the cause. It possesses something that wards off hordes of readers, yet still manages to attract a handful, who then embrace it and spread the word of its exquisite nature. The shell seekers among the readers, the slow walkers, those who stop and turn and bend over to pick up that one beautiful shell - they recognize her extraordinary work."''Jong, Oek de. ''Oek de Jong leest Maria Dermoût.'' (Amsterdam, 2005) P.7-8 [http://www.oekdejong.nl/#/in-translation/pfitem.php]
